newsitem.title: USA: Biospherics gets final license payment.
newsitem.headline: Biospherics gets final license payment.

text.p: Biospherics Inc said Tuesday it had received final payments from Denmark's MD Foods Ingredients on a license to manufacture a non-fattening sugar.

Biospherics, of Beltsville, Maryland, said it had received the remaining $750,000 in up-front money plus $1 million in non-refundable, advance royalties on the license to make the sugar, called D-tagatose.
The company, which developed the sugar, said it had received an initial payment of $750,000 from MD Foods in September.
Under the $2.5 million agreement, MD Foods will build the plants, produce the sugar and market it for low-calorie products like baked goods and ice cream.
"It's a significant deal for us," said Richard Levin, chief operating officer of Biospherics, adding that the Danish company will keep paying royalties on future sales, which should begin in 1998.
"If sales reach their projected levels, the license could be worth in excess of $500 million in pre-tax profit to the firm over the life of the license agreement," the company said in a news release.
Levin said the life of the agreement had not been determined.
He said MD Foods, a dairy products and technology company, would also hire Biospherics to conduct further research.
D-tagatose is a natural, full bulk sugar.
It does not raise blood sugar levels when consumed, making it safe for diabetics, the company said.
